WRITING.TITLE: Martha Nussbaum Interview: "There's no tension in supporting #MeToo and defending legal sex work"
New Popular Philosophy Column: 'Agora - A Marketplace of Ideas'
'Harassment, bullying, and intimidation are tactics unworthy of universities. Leave them to Trump and his minions.' -Jeff McMahan (Oxford) on no-platforming in the New Statesman
Judith Butler: The backlash against "gender ideology" must stop!
"What non-scientists believe about science is a matter of life and death" -Tim Williamson (Oxford) on climate change and the philosophy of science
Alia Al-Saji (McGill) on Banning Religious Symbols in Public
"The justification for national borders is weaker than we think" -Roger Crisp (Oxford) on John Locke, Brexit, and Borders
"If you think knowledge is expensive, try ignorance" -Simon Blackburn (Cambridge) on Post-truth and Fake News
"No end could justify these means!" -Philip Pettit (Princeton) on democracy, referendums, and re-thinking Brexit
"Games are fun, but they are also something more" -Tom Hurka (Toronto) on Wittgenstein and the Games We Play
"Technology has the potential to bring us together. It is up to us to unlock it" -Lisa Herzog (Munich) on technology in the workplace.
"In liberal democracies, should minorities have a claim to different rights?" -Paul Patton (UNSW) on liberalism and Indigenous rights
"We need not become Trump in order to defeat him. Let's offer through our resistance the model of a better world" -Todd May (Clemson) on non-violent resistance
"Meritocracy is not a casualty of the college admissions scandal, but its root cause" -Michael McLendon (Cal State) on Rousseau, Meritocracy, and Inequality
"Breaking up is hard to do!" -David Miller (Oxford) on secessionist movements, Brexit, and the philosophical foundations of the state
How to Deal with Domestic ISIS Fighters: Cecile Fabre (Oxford) on Justice, Treason, and Repatriation
"Work is an expression of our need to be needed" -Jeff Noonan on Automation, Labor, and the Problem with 'Post-Work'

"If animal rights activists remain orphans of the left, the result will be disastrous, not just for animals, but for humans and for the planet" -Will Kymlicka (Queen's) on Animal Rights, Humanism, and the Left
"Raising a child is a goal that can be chosen by a fully autonomous and flourishing human being" -Jonathan Webber on Existentialism, Parenting, and Simone de Beauvoir

"If we fail to respect the extraordinary universe in which we live, one day our descendants will regret that failing, as we now regret the damage we've done to Earth" -Peter Singer (Princeton) and Agata Sagan (Warsaw) on the ethics of space exploration
"What matters is not whether someone is principled, but whether they have been promoting genuinely good things" -Brian Weatherson (Michigan) on Value Pluralism and Praising Political Adversaries
"Most jokes are meant to be funny, but they are not always a laughing matter" -No #235;l Carroll on stereotypical humor and the philosophy of jokes
"Increased medical knowledge cannot justify the means of patient deception" -David Papineau (KCL) on placebo surgery and medical ethics
"Executives ought to face criminal punishment when they knowingly sell products that kill people" -Jeff McMahan (Oxford) on corporate wrongdoing
"Ancient philosophy was written by men, but the male thinkers we study philosophized with women" -Peter Adamson (KCL) on women in ancient philosophy
"Armstrong and Aldrin's initial moon landing is not a story of technological spin-offs, but speaks to something of deep human significance" -Tony Milligan (KCL) on the ethics of space travel
"Genuine equality and acceptance will only be achieved in a marriage free state" -Clare Chambers (Cambridge) on civil partnerships, marriage, and the law.
"Aesthetic life is a shining example of how we can embrace difference. Aesthetic tribalism robs us of that." -Dominic Lopes (UBC) on aesthetics and the politics of taste.
"Human rights are fundamental moral principles, but in their application less is sometimes more" -John Tasioulas (KCL) on human rights overreach.
"We can no longer afford to reduce nature to a resource waiting to be used at our command" -AJ Wendland (HSE) on Heidegger, Technology and the Climate Emergency.
"Calling gender vague does not mean anything goes. Rather, it is a way of appreciating that human life is complicated" -Carrie Jenkins (UBC) on Vagueness, Gender, and Relationships.
"Conspiracy theories are political propaganda and the best antidote is to expose their political agenda" -Quassim Cassam (Warwick) on the politics of conspiracy theories.
